resources.string: I would like to dedicate this program to my mother and wife for their unconditional support and leadership and to my kids for their unlimited excitement and energies.

The app "Stress Table US Customary" is developed to validate the design stress values used in the design calculation. The stress value at a given temperature is taken from ASME Section II Part D Table 1-A 2017 Edition for US Customary Unit. Necessary interpolation is implemented to give design stress value at intermediate temperature, where a value is provided in this app as "Nil" it is equivalent to "..." or vice versa.

This privacy policy has been compiled to better serve those who are concerned with how their \'Personally Identifiable Information\' (PII) is being used online. PII, as described in US privacy law and information security, is information that can be used on its own or with other information to identify, contact, or locate a single person, or to identify an individual in context. Please read our privacy policy carefully to get a clear understanding of how we collect, use, protect or otherwise handle your Personally Identifiable Information in accordance with our website.
What personal information do we collect from the people that visit our blog, website or app? When ordering or registering on our site, as appropriate, you may be asked to enter your name, email address, phone number or other details to help you with your experience.
When do we collect information? We collect information from you when you register on our site, subscribe to a newsletter, respond to a survey, fill out a form or enter information on our site.
How do we use your information?

Subscription automatically renews unless auto-renew is turned off at least 24 hours before the end of the current period. Account will be charged for renewal within 2-hours prior to the end of the current period. Subscription may be managed by the user manually by turning off the In-App Purchase of user account setting and then purchase the subscription within the app environment when required.
Auto-Renewal Subscription at the end of each year (Auto renewal can be turned off by going to Settings -> General -> Restrictions -> In-App Purchases of iOS device at any time)

This app is developed for quick reference and ease of use for stress value of specified material at given temperature. Every effort has been made to provide an accurate result, in case of discrepancy ASME Code stress values shall prevail.

The app "Stress Table US Customary" is developed to validate the design stress values used in the design calculation. The stress value at a given temperature is taken from ASME Section II Part D Table 1-A 2017 Edition for US Customary Unit. Necessary interpolation is implemented to give design stress value at intermediate temperature, where a value is provided in this app as "Nil" it is equivalent to "..." or vice versa.

Reliance Engineering and Services (RES) is dedicated to develop computer based tools and apps used in industrial and commercial application. Primarily focus is iOS and Android base application.
Our engineering apps are focused to facilitate engineering judgements, validate values used in the design calculation, generating welding documents, design tools for pressure items build to international code & standards and material procurement.

Some of the APP projects underway are, welding documents (WPQ, PQR, WPS), design verification of pressure item, tool to facilitate fabrication, material properties, fitness for service, international codes & standards for pressure application etc.
We also develop apps for commercial client involved in consumer markets. Some of the projects underway are online ordering, inventory management and customized business solution
For inquiry please write to

The app "Stress Table US Customary" is developed to validate the design stress values used in the design calculation. The stress value at a given temperature is taken from ASME Section II Part D Table 1-A 2017 Edition for US Customary Unit. Necessary interpolation is implemented to give design stress value at intermediate temperature, where a value is provided in this app as "Nil" it is equivalent to "..." or vice versa.

This app is developed for quick reference and ease of use for stress value of specified material at given temperature. This app does not intend to supersede the Code requirement nor to suggest any requirement which is not supported by the Code. User are strongly suggested to do manual check where there is a doubt. Also encourage to contact us for improvement and modification.
Every effort has been made to provide an accurate result, in case of discrepancy ASME Code stress values shall prevail.
The app developer or his organization holds no liability for the error or omission or for the consequence of any actions taken on the basis of information provided.
This app is intended for individuals who purchase it for specified period. Any illegal copying, downloading or mirroring of the app is against copyright and handled accordingly.

ROMs for wrist, Fingers and Thumb

•Patient should be in supine lying position.


Ask the patient to clasp/hold the affected hand with the help of unaffected hand.


Then flex both shoulders as demonstrated in the video.


Repeat this exercise 10 times.

•Patient should be in supine lying position.


Ask the patient to clasp/hold the affected hand with the help of unaffected hand.


Bring both arms at the level of 90° then move the arms right and left side as demonstrated in the video.


Repeat this exercise 10 times.

•Patient should be in supine lying position.


Ask the patient to abduct the affected arm as demonstrated in the video.


Repeat this exercise 10 times.

•Ask the patient to place the affected arm on the table.


Then bend (flex) and straighten (extend) the elbow as demonstrated in the video.


tKeep your body straight and shoulders back and avoid compensatory movemens of body.


Repeat this exercise 10 times.

•Ask the patient to place the affected arm on the table.


Perform the pronation and supination of elbow as demonstrated in the video.


Keep your body straight and shoulders back and avoid compensatory movements of body.


Repeat this exercise 10 times.

•Ask the patient to clasp/hold the affected hand with the help of unaffected hand.


Then bend and straighten the wrist as demonstrated in the video.


Keep your body straight and shoulders back and avoid compensatory movements of body.


Repeat this exercise 10 times.

•Patient should be sitting at the side of the table.


tAsk the patien to place affected arm on the table and straighten the elbow sideways as demonstrated in the video.


Keep your body straight and shoulders back and avoid compensatory movements of body.


Repeat this activity 10 times.

•Patient should be sitting at the side of the table.


Place a box on the table.


Ask the patient to place affected forearm on the box then remove it as demonstrated in the video.


Keep your body straight and shoulders back and avoid compensatory movements of body.


Repeat this activity 10 times.

•Patient should be sitting in front of the table.


Place a box on the table.


Ask the patient to place affected hand on the box then remove it as demonstrated in the video.


Keep your body straight and shoulders back and avoid compensatory movements of body.


Repeat this activity 10 times.

•Sit in front of the table and place a can on the table.


Lift can with your affected hand.


Then place it back on the table.


Keep your body straight and shoulders back and avoid compensatory movements of body.


Repeat this activity 10 times.

•Sit in front of the table and place a pencil on the table.


Lift pencil with your affected hand.


Then place it back on the table.


Keep your body straight and shoulders back and avoid compensatory movements of body.


Repeat this activity 10 times.

1. Sit in front of the table and place paper clip on the table.


2. Lift paper clip with your affected hand.


3. Then place it back on the table.


4. Keep your body straight and shoulders back and avoid compensatory movements of body.


5. Repeat this activity 10 times.

•Sit in front of the table and place three cards on the table.


Flip cards one by one with your affected hand.


Keep your body straight and shoulders back and avoid compensatory movements of body.


Repeat this activity 10 times.

•Sit in front of the table and place a towel on the table.


Fold it as demonstrated in the video with your affected hand.


Then unfold it.


Keep your body straight and shoulders back and avoid compensatory movements of body.


Repeat this activity 10 times.

•Sit in front of the table and place a glass of water on the table.


Hold it with your affected hand.


Then bring it close to your mouth and drink.


Keep your body straight and shoulders back and avoid compensatory movements of body.

•Sit in front of the table and place a glass on the table.


Lift a glass of water at the angle of 90° shoulder flexion with elbow extended.


Keep your body straight and shoulders back and avoid compensatory movements of body.


Repeat this activity 10 times.

•Sit in front of the table, place 5 crystals (or any alternate items) and an empty box/jar on the table.


Pick the crystals one by one and put them inside the box/jar with your affected hand.


Keep your body straight and shoulders back and avoid compensatory movements of body.

•Sit in front of the table and place a towel on the table.


Extend your elbow to reach the towel then wipe the table with with your affected hand.


Keep elbow extended while wiping.


Keep your body straight and shoulders back and avoid compensatory movements of body.


Repeat this activity 10 times.

•Grasp a 6cm diameter ball with your affected hand.


Then squeeze the ball in your hand and release it.


Keep your body straight and shoulders back and avoid compensatory movements of body.


Repeat this activity 10 times.

•Sit in front of the table and place a comb on the table.


Lift a comb from the table with your affected hand.


Then comb your hair.


Keep your body straight and shoulders back and avoid compensatory movements of body.


Repeat this activity 10 times.

•Sit in front of the table and place food on the table.


Hold the spoon with your affected hand.


Put the food in the spoon.


Then bring the spoon close to your mouth and eat.


Keep your body straight and shoulders back and avoid compensatory movements of body.

•Sit in front of the table and place a jar on the table.


Hold the jar with your unaffected hand.


Open the lid of the jar with your affected hand.


Keep your body straight and shoulders back and avoid compensatory movements of body.


Repeat this activity 10 times.

•Patient should be in supine lying position.


Caregiver should be standing at the side of patient.


Hold the patient’s affected arm from the wrist then bend the elbow and straighten it as demonstrated in the video.


Repeat this exercise 10 times.

•Patient should be in supine lying position.


Caregiver should be standing at the side of patient.


Hold the patient’s affected arm from the wrist then bend the wrist first then straighten it as demonstrated in the video.


Repeat this exercise 10 times.


Hold the affected arm from wrist then move the thumb and fingers in all possible directions and return to original position.


Repeat this exercise 10 times.

•Patient should be in supine lying position.


Caregiver should be standing at the side of patient.


Hold the patient’s arm at the level of elbow and hand as demonstrated in the video.


Perform the flexion of shoulder as demonstrated in the video.


Repeat this exercise 10 times.

A stroke, sometimes called a “brain attack,” occurs when blood flow to the brain is interrupted. When a stroke occurs, brain cells in the immediate area begin to die because they stop getting the oxygen and nutrients they need to function. This can cause lasting brain damage, long-term disability, or even death.

If your stroke affected the right side of your brain, your movement and sensation on the left side of your body may be affected. If your stroke damaged the brain tissue on the left side of your brain, your movement and sensation on the right side of your body may be affected. Brain damage to the left side of your brain may cause speech and language disorders.

string.name: header2
string.u: What are the types of stroke?

resources.string:
The three main types of stroke are:

1)Ischemic stroke is caused by a blood clot that blocks or plugs a blood vessel in the brain. Blocked or narrowed blood vessels are caused by fatty deposits that build up in blood vessels or by blood clots or other debris that travel through your bloodstream and lodge in the blood vessels in your brain. This is the most common type; about 80 percent of strokes are ischemic.

2)Hemorrhagic stroke is caused by a blood vessel that breaks and bleeds into the brain. The leaked blood puts too much pressure on brain cells, which damages them. High blood pressure and aneurysms—balloon-like bulges in an artery that can stretch and burst—are examples of conditions that can cause a hemorrhagic stroke. There are two types of hemorrhagic strokes: 

•Intracerebral hemorrhage is the most common type of hemorrhagic stroke. It occurs when an artery in the brain bursts, flooding the surrounding tissue with blood. 

•Subarachnoid hemorrhage is a less common type of hemorrhagic stroke. It refers to bleeding in the area between the brain and the thin tissues that cover it.

3)Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) Another condition that's similar to a stroke. It's sometimes called a "mini-stroke." TIAs happen when the blood supply to the brain is blocked for a short time- usually no more than 5 minutes. The damage to the brain cells isn't permanent, but if you have had a TIA, you are at a much higher risk of having a stroke. Recognizing and treating TIAs can lower the risk of a major stroke. If you have a TIA, your health care team can find the cause and take steps to prevent a major stroke.

string.name: header3
string.u: Who is at risk for a stroke?

resources.string:
Certain factors can raise your risk of a stroke. The major risk factors include 

•High blood pressure. This is the primary risk factor for a stroke. 

•Diabetes. 

•Heart diseases. Atrial fibrillation and other heart diseases can cause blood clots that lead to stroke. 

•Smoking. When you smoke, you damage your blood vessels and raise your blood pressure. 

•A personal or family history of stroke or TIA. 

•Age. Your risk of stroke increases as you get older. 

•Race and ethnicity. African Americans have a higher risk of stroke. There are also other factors that are linked to a higher risk of stroke, such as 

•Alcohol and illegal drug use 

•Not getting enough physical activity 

•High cholesterol 

•Unhealthy diet 

•Having obesity

"The symptoms of stroke often happen quickly. They include 

•Sudden numbness or weakness of the face, arm, or leg (especially on one side of the body) 

•Sudden confusion, trouble speaking, or understanding speech 

•Sudden trouble seeing in one or both eyes 

•Sudden difficulty walking, dizziness, loss of balance or coordination 

•Sudden severe headache with no known cause

Some of the tests you may have include: 

•A physical exam. Your doctor will do a number of tests you're familiar with, such as listening to your heart and checking your blood pressure. You'll also have a neurological exam to see how a potential stroke is affecting your nervous system. o

Your mental alertness o

Your coordination and balance o

Any numbness or weakness in your face, arms, and legs o

Any trouble speaking and seeing clearly 

•Blood tests 

•Computerized tomography (CT) scan 

•Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) 

•Carotid ultrasound 

•Cerebral angiogram 

•Echocardiogram Heart tests, which can help detect heart problems or blood clots that may have led to a stroke.

string.name: header6
string.u: What are the treatments for stroke?

resources.string:
Treatments for stroke include medicines, surgery, and rehabilitation. Which treatments you get depend on the type of stroke and the stage of treatment. The different stages are 

•Acute treatment, to try to stop a stroke while it is happening 

•Post-stroke rehabilitation, to overcome the disabilities caused by the stroke 

•Prevention, to prevent a first stroke or, if you have already had one, prevent another stroke Can strokes be prevented? If you have already had a stroke or are at risk of having a stroke, you can make some heart-healthy lifestyle changes to try to prevent a future stroke: 

•Managing your blood pressure and cholesterol levels 

•Managing diabetes. 

•Quitting smoking 

•Avoiding alcohol. 

•Treating obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). 

•Avoiding illegal drugs. 

•Eating a heart-healthy diet 

•Aiming for a healthy weight 

•Managing stress 

•Getting regular physical activity or exercise If these changes aren't enough, you may need medicine to control your risk factors.

string.name: header7
string.u: What disabilities can result from a stroke?

resources.string:
Although stroke is a disease of the brain, it can affect the entire body. A stroke can sometimes cause temporary or permanent disabilities, depending on how long the brain lacks blood flow and which part was affected. Complications may include: 

•Paralysis or loss of muscle movement. You may become paralyzed on one side of your body, or lose control of certain muscles, such as those on one side of your face or one arm. 

•Difficulty talking or swallowing. 

•Memory loss or thinking difficulties. 

•Emotional problems. 

•Pain. 

•Changes in behavior and self-care ability.

string.name: header8
string.u: What are the symptoms of stroke?
